text: we're here to talk today about a new tool called metal cubed that is specifically designed to provision nodes
in a kubernetes cluster and I'm gonna give a little bit of background about the project and talk a little bit about
the design and then Russell's gonna do some demos for you so the first question
I'm sure all of you are asking yourself is why did we build another tool to provision servers there's the bazillion
tools out there already that do that and we've been doing it for years and years and what is the point of having another tool so we have three main reasons that
drove us creating this new project the first is that we wanted something that
had a kubernetes native API so that a cube admin who was working with their
cluster could use the same tools to administer the infrastructure underneath the cluster that they used to administer
the applications that run on top of it we also wanted the tool to be self hosted so that it would run in the
cluster so you don't have to deploy something separately in order to manage your clusters and then we also wanted
the tool to manage the cluster itself so we've tied in with the machine API from
Sigma cluster life cycle so that once you have the tool installed everything
works just the same way it would is if you had a cloud-based cluster so you're operating your bare metal cluster in the
same way that you would if you were on Amazon or Google or whatever so let's
look at the pieces of the system and talk a little bit about the design and how it works I mentioned that we wanted to have
kubernetes native API so the API for metal cubed is a new CRD called the bare
metal host and that gives us a little bit of information about the host so that we can manage it so we need things
like the credentials and the location of the base board management controller and then some information about it so we can
recognize it when it come show up on the network so we get things like a MAC address and stuff like that that
information is used by the bare metal operator which drives the provisioning
process by invoking the ironic REST API so ironic is a provisioning tool that
came out of the OpenStack community it's got a nice REST API for doing provisioning and it knows how work with a lot of different kinds of
hardware and by adopting that we were able to really bootstrap the project and make a lot of a lot more progress than
if we had started from scratch ironic is deployed with metal cubes so
you don't have to stand up a separate set of ironic services you don't have to manage that it's all managed as part of
managing metal cube itself ironic we'll use the image that you have hosted in
your image registry and it will take some config drive data that we pass it and it will deploy the image to the
server and reboot the server to run whatever that image is so this level of
this layer of the components is basically a generic provisioning tool that wraps up an existing API in a
kubernetes native API so that gives us two of our three goals we've got that kubernetes native out API and it's self
hosted running in the cluster that you're working with and in order to meet our third goal of having it be self
managing that's where we tie in with the machine API the machine API is out of
the cig cluster life cycle group it defines things like machine set and machine which allow you to they were
kind of like deployments and pods that lets you scale up your cluster using different criteria and so we've
implemented a provider that plugs into that looks for machines that specify that they want to be bare bare metal
machines and then the actuator knows how to take that information and configure
the host and drive the provisioning process so that it becomes a node in your cluster all right so I've mentioned
three different representations for the same sort of piece of your cluster we
get this question a lot why do we have nodes and machines and hosts nodes I'm
sure everybody is familiar with that concept that's the basic concept built into kubernetes basically where you have
a cubelet running the machine is the new thing that comes from the signal Uster life cycle group and the work that
they're doing there and that's you think of it as a request to have a cubelet run somewhere and when you're running in a
cloud environment what happens is the provider calls out to the cloud API creates a new
configures that instance to become a node and then uses the machine resource to keep track of the instance and track
the information about it and that's really thing well in a bare-metal environment we don't have a cloud API we
have to become the cloud API and so that's what the host resources for that gives us that API that we can call out
to and trigger provisioning trigger configuration and the host resource
becomes inventory so you you're tracking all of your inventory that's available to your cluster at the same time so
let's look at the details of what a host actually looks like I mentioned that we
need the base management controller credentials and locations so that's here in the BMC fields we've support a couple
of different kinds of BMC's for different hardware vendors so there's the URL specify as what protocol to use
and then a location on the network where we can find it and the credentials are stored in a secret so that those are all
protected and we just you know read the secret inside the operator when we need it to talk to ironic the consumer ref
field is used to keep track of which hosts are actually being consumed by some other systems so in this case it's
been allocated to a machine so it's going to be provisioned or it has been provisioned as a worker node in this
cluster if you were using the lower-level api yourself to provision other things you could put some other
reference in there just to sort of keep it as a placeholder to indicate that that host was being used the image
fields control what image has actually been provisioned to the host so if you
want to reprovision the host with a newer image you would change the URL there and we would trigger that would
trigger Reaper visioning writing a new image to that disk and then the user data field points to a secret that
contains information that we passed a config drive so that during the boot process you can have you can inject your
SSH keys or anything like that and we use that with an open shift to inject the ignition configuration data so
that's the spec section of the host the status section includes some information that we can learn about the host as we
inspect it and do provisioning so the hardware fields collect information
about all of the CPUs all of the network interfaces all the storage that's available I've abbreviated this we
actually collect quite a lot of information that's available about what's in the host and you can use that
to select which host you want so you can select only hosts that have a certain amount of ram to be a part of certain
machine sets and things like that the operational status field is basically an
error indicator if we can't talk to the management controller or if the Machine suddenly stops working correctly in some
other way we're gonna reflect the error in that field and then that provisioning section at the bottom is showing what
actually was provision to the host so you have the instructions in the spec and you have the the actual reality in
